column2: THE TWO BIBLICAL ACCOUNTS OF THE FLOOD.
column3: THE TWO BIBLICAL ACCOUNTS OF THE FLOOD.

column2: Careful readers of Genesis 6-9 have long recognized certain difficulties in interpreting the narrative as it now stands.
column3: Careful readers of genesis chapters six to nine have long recognized certain difficulties in interpreting the narrative as it now stands.

column2: Thus, for example, in 6:20 Noah is commanded to take into the ark two of every kind of beast and bird; but in 7:2, 3 he is commanded to take in seven of all the clean beasts and birds.
column3: Thus, for example, in six twenty Noah is commanded to take into the ark two of every kind of beast and bird; but in seven to two, three he is commanded to take in seven of all the clean beasts and birds.

column2: According to 7:4, 12 the flood came as the result of a forty days' rain; but according to 7:11 it was because the fountains of the great deep were broken up and the windows of heaven were opened.
column3: According to seven to four, twelve the flood came as the result of a forty days' rain; but according to seven eleven it was because the fountains of the great deep were broken up and the windows of heaven were opened.

column2: Again, according to 7:17, the flood continued on the earth forty days; while according to 7:24 its duration was a hundred and fifty days.
column3: Again, according to seven seventeen, the flood continued on the earth forty days; while according to seven twenty four its duration was a hundred and fifty days.

column2: These fundamental variations and the presence of duplicate versions of the same incidents point, some writers think, to two originally distinct accounts of the flood which have been closely woven together by the final editor of the book of Genesis.
column3: These fundamental variations and the presence of duplicate versions of the same incidents point, some writers think, to two originally distinct accounts of the flood which have been closely woven together by the final editor of the book of genesis.

column2: When these two accounts are disentangled, they are each practically complete and apparently represent variant versions of the same flood story. (See _Hist.
column3: When these two accounts are disentangled, they are each practically complete and apparently represent variant versions of the same flood story. (See underscore Hist.

column2: In this account the number seven prevails.
column3: In this account the number seven prevails.

column2: Seven of each clean beast and bird are taken into the ark to provide food for Noah and his family.
column3: Seven of each clean beast and bird are taken into the ark to provide food for Noah and his family.

column2: Seven days the waters rose, and at intervals of seven days he sent out a raven and a dove.
column3: Seven days the waters rose, and at intervals of seven days he sent out a raven and a dove.

column2: The flood from its beginning to the time when Noah disembarked continued sixty-eight days.
column3: The flood from its beginning to the time when Noah disembarked continued sixty eight days.

column2: At the end, when he had determined by sending out birds that the waters had subsided, he went forth from the ark and reared an altar and offered sacrifice to Jehovah of every clean beast and bird.

column2: The other and more detailed account is apparently the sequel of the late priestly narratives found in Genesis 1 and 5.
column3: The other and more detailed account is apparently the sequel of the late priestly narratives found in genesis chapter one and five.

column2: The style is that of a legal writer--formal, exact and repetitious.
column3: The style is that of a legal writer-formal, exact and repetitious.

column2: In this account only two of each kind of beast and bird are taken into the ark.
column3: In this account only two of each kind of beast and bird are taken into the ark.

column2: The flood lasts for over a year and is universal, covering even the tops of the highest mountains.
column3: The flood lasts for over a year and is universal, covering even the tops of the highest mountains.

column2: No animals are sacrificed, for according to the priestly writer this custom was first instituted by Moses.
column3: No animals are sacrificed, for according to the priestly writer this custom was first instituted by Moses.

column2: When the flood subsides, however, a covenant is concluded and is sealed by the rainbow in accordance with which man's commission to rule over all other living things is renewed and divine permission is given to each to eat of the flesh of animals, provided only that men carefully abstain from eating the blood.

column2: THE CORRESPONDING BABYLONIAN FLOOD STORIES.
column3: THE CORRESPONDING BABYLONIAN FLOOD STORIES.

column2: Closely parallel to these two variant Biblical accounts of the flood are the two Babylonian versions, which have fortunately been almost wholly recovered.
column3: Closely parallel to these two variant Biblical accounts of the flood are the two Babylonian versions, which have fortunately been almost wholly recovered.

column2: The older Babylonian account is found in the eleventh tablet of the Gilgamesh epic, which comes from the library of Asshurbanipal.
column3: The older Babylonian account is found in the eleventh tablet of the Gilgamesh epic, which comes from the library of Asshurbanipal.

column2: This great conqueror lived contemporaneously with Manasseh during whose reign Assyrian influence was paramount in the kingdom of Judah.
column3: This great conqueror lived contemporaneously with Manasseh during whose reign Assyrian influence was paramount in the kingdom of Judah.

column2: In his quest for healing and immortality Gilgamesh reached the abode of the Babylonian hero of the flood.
column3: In his quest for healing and immortality Gilgamesh reached the abode of the Babylonian hero of the flood.

column2: In response to Gilgamesh's question as to how he, a mortal, attained immortality the Babylonian Noah recounts the story of the flood.
column3: In response to Gilgamesh's question as to how he, a mortal, attained immortality the Babylonian Noah recounts the story of the flood.

column2: It was brought about by the Babylonian gods in order to destroy the city of Shurippak, situated on the banks of the Euphrates.
column3: It was brought about by the Babylonian gods in order to destroy the city of Shurippak, situated on the banks of the Euphrates.

column2: The god Ea gave the warning to his worshipper, the hero of the flood, and commanded him:
column3: The god Ea gave the warning to his worshipper, the hero of the flood, and commanded him:

column2: Construct a house, build a ship, Leave goods, look after life, Forsake possessions, and save life, Cause all kinds of living things to go up into the ship. The ship which thou shalt build,-- Exact shall be its dimensions: Its breadth shall equal its length; On the great deep launch it. I understood and said to Ea, my lord: "Behold, my lord, what thou hast commanded, I have reverently received and will carry out."
column3: Construct a house, build a ship, Leave goods, look after life, Forsake possessions, and save life, Cause all kinds of living things to go up into the ship. The ship which thou shalt build,-- Exact shall be its dimensions: Its breadth shall equal its length; On the great deep launch it. I understood and said to Ea, my lord: "Behold, my lord, what thou hast commanded, I have reverently received and will carry out."

column2: A detailed account then follows of the building of the ark.
column3: A detailed account then follows of the building of the ark.

column2: Its dimensions were one hundred and twenty cubits in each direction. It was built in six stories, each of which was divided into nine parts.
column3: Its dimensions were one hundred and twenty cubits in each direction. It was built in six stories, each of which was divided into nine parts.

column2: Plentiful provisions were next carried on board and a great feast was held to commemorate the completion of the ark.
column3: Plentiful provisions were next carried on board and a great feast was held to commemorate the completion of the ark.

column2: After carrying on board his treasures of silver and gold he adds:
column3: After carrying on board his treasures of silver and gold he adds:

column2: All the living creatures of all kinds I loaded on it. I brought on board my family and household; Cattle of the field, beasts of the field, the craftsmen, All of them I brought on board.
column3: All the living creatures of all kinds I loaded on it. I brought on board my family and household; Cattle of the field, beasts of the field, the craftsmen, All of them I brought on board.

column2: In the evening at the command of the god Shamash the rains began to descend.
column3: In the evening at the command of the god Shamash the rains began to descend.

column2: Then the Babylonian Noah entered the ship and closed the door and entrusted the great house with its contents to the captain.
column3: Then the Babylonian Noah entered the ship and closed the door and entrusted the great house with its contents to the captain.

column2: The description of the tempest that follows is exceedingly vivid and picturesque.
column3: The description of the tempest that follows is exceedingly vivid and picturesque.

column2: When the first light of dawn shone forth, There rose from the horizon a dark cloud, within which Adad thundered, Nabu and Marduk marched at the front, The heralds passed over mountains and land; Nergal tore out the ship's mast, Ninib advanced, following up the attack, The spirits of earth raised torches, With their sheen they lighted up the world. Adad's tempest reached to heaven, And all light was changed to darkness. So great was the havoc wrought by the storm that The gods bowed down, sat there weeping, Close pressed together were their lips.
column3: When the first light of dawn shone forth, There rose from the horizon a dark cloud, within which Adad thundered, Nabu and Marduk marched at the front, The heralds passed over mountains and land; Nergal tore out the ship's mast, Ninib advanced, following up the attack, The spirits of earth raised torches, With their sheen they lighted up the world. Adad's tempest reached to heaven, And all light was changed to darkness. So great was the havoc wrought by the storm that The gods bowed down, sat there weeping, Close pressed together were their lips.

column2: For six days and nights the storm raged, but on the seventh day it subsided and the flood began to abate.
column3: For six days and nights the storm raged, but on the seventh day it subsided and the flood began to abate.

column3: Of the race of mortals, however, every voice was hushed.

column2: When the seventh day arrived, I sent forth a dove and let it loose, The dove went forth, but came back; Because it found no resting-place, it returned: Then I sent forth a swallow, but it came back; Because it found no resting-place, it returned. Then I sent forth a raven and let it loose, The raven went forth and saw that the waters had decreased; It fed, it waded, it croaked, but did not return. Then I sent forth everything in all directions, and offered a sacrifice, I made an offering of incense on the highest peak of the mountain, Seven and seven bowls I placed there, And over them I poured out calamus, cedar wood and fragrant herbs. The gods inhaled the odor, The gods inhaled the sweet odor, The gods gathered like flies above the sacrifice.

column2: At the command of the god he built a great ship fifteen stadia long and two in width.
column3: At the command of the god he built a great ship fifteen stadia long and two in width.

column2: Into this he took not only his family and provisions, but quadrupeds and birds of all kinds. When the flood began to recede, he sent out a bird, which quickly returned.
column3: Into this he took not only his family and provisions, but quadrupeds and birds of all kinds. When the flood began to recede, he sent out a bird, which quickly returned.

column3: After a few days he sent forth another bird, which returned with mud on its feet.

column3: When the third bird failed to return, he took off the cover of the ship and found that it had stranded on a mountain of Armenia.

column2: The mountain in the Biblical account is identified with Mount Ararat.
column3: The mountain in the Biblical account is identified with Mount Ararat.

column2: Disembarking, the Babylonian Noah kissed the earth and, after building an altar, offered a sacrifice to the gods.
column3: Disembarking, the Babylonian Noah kissed the earth and, after building an altar, offered a sacrifice to the gods.

column2: Thus the variations between the older and later Babylonian accounts of the flood correspond in general to those that have been already noted in the Biblical versions.

column2: III.
column3: three.

column2: HISTORY OF THE BIBLICAL FLOOD STORIES.
column3: HISTORY OF THE BIBLICAL FLOOD STORIES.

column2: On the basis of the preceding comparisons some writers attempt to trace tentatively the history of the flood tradition current among the peoples of southwestern Asia.
column3: On the basis of the preceding comparisons some writers attempt to trace tentatively the history of the flood tradition current among the peoples of southwestern Asia.

column2: A fragment of the Babylonian flood story, coming from at least as early as 2000 B.C., has recently been discovered.
column3: A fragment of the Babylonian flood story, coming from at least as early as two thousand b c, has recently been discovered.

column2: The probability is that the tradition goes back to the earliest beginnings of Babylonian history.
column3: The probability is that the tradition goes back to the earliest beginnings of Babylonian history.

column2: The setting of the Biblical accounts of the flood is also the Tigris-Euphrates valley rather than Palestine.
column3: The setting of the Biblical accounts of the flood is also the Tigris Euphrates valley rather than Palestine.

column2: The description of the construction of the ark in Genesis 6:14-16 is not only closely parallel to that found in the Babylonian account, but the method--the smearing of the ark within and without with bitumen--is peculiar to the Tigris-Euphrates valley.
column3: The description of the construction of the ark in genesis chapter six verses fourteen to sixteen is not only closely parallel to that found in the Babylonian account, but the method-the smearing of the ark within and without with bitumen-is peculiar to the Tigris Euphrates valley.

column2: Many scholars believe, therefore, that Babylonia was the original home of the Biblical flood story.
column3: Many scholars believe, therefore, that Babylonia was the original home of the Biblical flood story.

column2: Its exact origin, however, is not so certain.
column3: Its exact origin, however, is not so certain.

column2: Many of its details were doubtless suggested by the annual floods and fogs which inundate that famous valley and recall the primeval chaos so vividly pictured in the corresponding Babylonian story of the creation.
column3: Many of its details were doubtless suggested by the annual floods and fogs which inundate that famous valley and recall the primeval chaos so vividly pictured in the corresponding Babylonian story of the creation.

column2: It may have been based on the remembrances of a great local inundation, possibly due to the subsidence of great areas of land.
column3: It may have been based on the remembrances of a great local inundation, possibly due to the subsidence of great areas of land.

column2: In the earliest Hebrew records there is no trace of this tradition, although it may have been known to the Aramean ancestors of the Hebrews.
column3: In the earliest Hebrew records there is no trace of this tradition, although it may have been known to the Aramean ancestors of the hebrews.

column2: The literary evidence, however, suggests that it was first brought to Palestine by the Assyrians.
column3: The literary evidence, however, suggests that it was first brought to Palestine by the Assyrians.

column2: During the reactionary reign of Manasseh, Assyrian customs and Baylonian ideas, which these conquerors had inherited, inundated Judah.
column3: During the reactionary reign of Manasseh, Assyrian customs and Baylonian ideas, which these conquerors had inherited, inundated Judah.

column2: Even in the temple at Jerusalem the Babylonians' gods, the host of heaven, were worshipped by certain of the Hebrews.
column3: Even in the temple at Jerusalem the Babylonians' gods, the host of heaven, were worshipped by certain of the hebrews.

column2: The few literary inscriptions which come from this period, those found in the mound at Gezer, are written in the Assyrian script and contain the names of Assyrian officials.
column3: The few literary inscriptions which come from this period, those found in the mound at Gezer, are written in the Assyrian script and contain the names of Assyrian officials.

column2: Later when the Jewish exiles were carried to Babylonia, they naturally came into contact again with the Babylonian account of the flood, but in its later form, as the comparisons already instituted clearly indicate.
column3: Later when the Jewish exiles were carried to Babylonia, they naturally came into contact again with the Babylonian account of the flood, but in its later form, as the comparisons already instituted clearly indicate.

column2: It is thus possible, these scholars believe, to trace, in outline at least, the literary history of the Semitic flood story in its various transformations through a period of nearly two thousand years.
column3: It is thus possible, these scholars believe, to trace, in outline at least, the literary history of the Semitic flood story in its various transformations through a period of nearly two thousand years.
